questions.question: Question 1: Coronaviruses are

options.d: Variably enveloped viruses with a complex symmetry

questions.explanation:
Coronaviruses are enveloped helically symmetrical viruses. Being enveloped contributes to their lipid solvent susceptibility. This is the reason alcohol-based 
hand sanitizers and soaps are used. The lipid membrane dissolution and protein denaturation by 
ethanol lead to membrane disruption and inhibition of metabolism. The coronaviridiae have a single unsegmented ss (+) RNA, which is the largest genome among 
RNA viruses. They are about 120- 160 nm in size and contain a helical nucleocapsid. A total of

questions.question:
Question 2: An elderly diabetic man presents with difficulty breathing, cough, and fever. He came back 
after visiting his son in New York, 10 days ago. His SpO2 is 89%. HRCT shows bilateral, 
multilobar ground-glass opacification. What is the receptor used by the likely causative 
organism to gain entry into the cells?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette showing breathlessness, fever, and cough with a low oxygen saturation 
and ground-glass opacities on HRCT is indicative of COVID-19 caused by 
the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE-2) is the specific functional 
receptor for SARS-CoV-2 in human cells. ACE2 is expressed in nearly all human organs in varying degrees. In the respiratory system, ACE2 
is mainly expressed by the type 2 alveolar epithelial cells in the highest quantity. Hence, the 
primary target of SARS-CoV-2 is type 2 alveolar cells. The functional receptor for SARS-CoV (SARS 2002) is also ACE 2. Note: Dipeptidylpeptidase 4 is the functional receptor for MERS-CoV (MERS 2012). 1513 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: Which viral structure determines the infectious nature and host specificity of SARS-CoV-2? 1508 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Spike protein (marked as 1 in the image) determines the infectious nature and host specificity of 
SARS-CoV-2. The spike protein also referred to as the CoV S protein is one of the key components determining 
virus virulence, tissue tropism, and host range. The coronavirus spike protein mediates 
coronavirus entry into host cells. Each spike protein has two distinct subunits S1 and S2. • S1 subunit is responsible for binding to the specific receptor (ACE 2) on the host cell surface 
facilitating viral attachment to the surface of target cells. • S2 subunit drives the fusion of the viral and host cell membranes. The host protease enzymes, mainly transmembrane protease serine-type 2 (TMPRSS2) cleave the 
spike protein. This activates the spike protein to induce virus-cell membrane fusion at the cell 
surface and allows the entry of coronaviruses into the host cell.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following scenarios is unlikely for transmission of SARS-CoV-2?

options.a: A gym trainer transmitted the virus to his client following a sudden, involuntary cough.
options.b: A librarian got infected from a reader through the share and exchange of books.
options.c: A resident transmitted the virus to his neighbour who entered the same apartment lift after a
options.d: A thalassemic girl got infected following routine blood transfusion.

questions.explanation:
Blood transfusion is not a mode of transmission of SARS-CoV-2. Option A: Droplet transmission • A type of direct transmission • Occurs when someone coughs, sneezes, speaks, or spits • Virus-containing droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air directly contact 
another person’s conjunctiva, oral or nasal mucosa • Limited to about 6 feet distance between the source and the host 1514 
Sold by @itachibot • Particle size is 5-10 µm in diameter Option B: Fomite transmission • A type of indirect transmission • Objects other than water or food contaminated by infectious agents - clothes, towels, linen, cups, 
spoons, pencils, books, toys, door handles, taps, etc. • Transmission occurs when one touches the contaminated objects and touches his mouth, nose, 
or eyes Option C: Airborne - droplet nuclei transmission • A type of indirect transmission • Droplet nuclei - dried residue of droplets of size <5µm that are generated by the evaporation of 
droplets coughed or sneezed into the air and by a variety of atomizing devices • Remain infectious when suspended in the air for some time (typically hours) • Transmission occurs when one inhales droplet nuclei/aerosols containing the virus in sufficient 
quantity

questions.question:
Question 5: A relative of a COVID-19 positive man, who came in his contact yesterday, reported to the flu 
clinic. Within how many days is he most likely to develop the disease?
questions.explanation:
The incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 infection ranges from 1-14 days so he is most likely to 
develop the disease after this period. The median incubation period is around 4-6 days. The incubation period is defined as the time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and 
appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease.

questions.question: Question 6: Covid 19 outbreak is a type of which of the following kinds of the epidemic?
questions.explanation:
The outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a propagated epidemic. The propagated epidemic results from person-to-person transmission of the infectious agent over 
a prolonged duration of time. Other examples of this type include hepatitis A and polio.

questions.question: Question 7: What is not included in the definition of a suspect case of SARS-CoV-2?
questions.explanation:
All of the given symptoms are included in the definition of a suspect case of 
SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 except convulsions. As per WHO and MOHFW, a suspect case is defined as: • A person who meets the clinical and epidemiological criteria- • Clinical criteria: • Acute onset of fever AND cough; OR 1515 
Sold by @itachibot • Acute onset of any 3 or more of the following: fever, cough, general weakness/ fatigue, headache, 
myalgia, sore throat, coryza, dyspnoea, anorexia/nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, altered mental status. • Epidemiological criteria: A person present in any of the following settings for 14 days prior to 
symptom onset- • Residing or working in an area with a high risk of transmission of virus OR • Residing or travel to an area with community transmission OR • Working in any healthcare setting • A patient with severe acute respiratory illness with- • history of fever or measured fever of 38 C° along with cough • onset within the last 10 days • requiring hospitalization • An asymptomatic person not meeting epidemiologic criteria with a positive SARS-CoV-2 
antigen-RDT.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not considered a probable case of SARS-CoV-2?

options.a: An asymptomatic contact of a probable case with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test.
options.b: A person with acute onset fever and cough who is a contact of a confirmed case.
options.c: A suspect case with positive chest radiological findings suggestive of COVID-19 disease.
options.d: A person with recent onset of anosmia or ageusia in the absence of any other identified cause.

questions.explanation:
An asymptomatic contact of a probable case with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test is 
considered as a confirmed case, and not a probable case. Probable case is defined as: • A patient who meets clinical criteria and is a contact of a probable or confirmed case, or linked 
to a COVID-19 cluster. • A suspect case with chest imaging showing findings suggestive of COVID-19 disease. • A person with recent onset of anosmia or ageusia in the absence of any other identified cause. • Death, not otherwise explained, in an adult with respiratory distress preceding death and was a 
contact of a probable or confirmed case or linked to a COVID-19 cluster. Confirmed case is defined as: • A person with a positive Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) including RT-PCR or any other 
similar test approved by ICMR. • A person with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test and meeting either the probable case 
definition or suspect criteria. • An asymptomatic person with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test who is a contact of a 
probable or confirmed case.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following people would you not classify as a high risk contact of SARS-CoV2?

options.a: A family member who lives in the same household as the patient
options.b: A doctor who examined the patient with a surgical mask and gloves
options.c: A passenger in the same bus as a symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested
options.d: A sanitary worker who cleaned the linens of the patient

questions.explanation:
A person traveling in the same environment and not having significant exposure to the confirmed 
case is not classified as a high-risk contact. 1516 
Sold by @itachibot A contact of COVID-19 is a person living in the same household or having direct physical contact 
with the patient/infectious secretions without appropriate PPE or a person who was in a closed 
environment or at a distance of within 1 meter of a COVID-19 case. High-risk contacts: • Touched body fluids of the patient • Had direct contact with the body of the patient during the physical examination without proper 
PPE • Touched or cleaned the linens, clothes, or dishes of the patient • Lives in the same household as the patient • Comes in close contact (within 1 meter) with the patient without necessary precautions • A passenger in close proximity with the symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later 
tested positive Low-risk contacts: • Shared the same space but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case. • Travelled in the same environment but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.

questions.question:
Question 10: You would classify all of the following patients as having major risk factors for severe 
COVID-19 except:

options.a: A 19 year old female undergoing dialysis for CKD
options.b: A 49 year old male who has recently undergone liver transplantation
options.c: A 42 year old man who had malaria 2 months ago
options.d: A 65 year old male with no comorbidities

questions.explanation:
A middle-aged man who had malaria 2 months ago is not at major risk of developing severe 
COVID-19 disease. The major risk factors for severe COVID-19 are: • Increasing age (>60 years) • Underlying non-communicable diseases • Cardiac disease • Chronic lung disease • Cerebrovascular disease • Hypertension • Diabetes • Obesity • Chronic kidney disease • Immune suppression • Cancer

questions.question:
Question 11: A woman presents with breathlessness and hemoptysis since yesterday. Examination findings 
are given below. CT scan shows localised ground-glass opacity in the left posterior lobe of the 
lung. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
1517 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19. Hemoptysis is one of the atypical 
manifestations of COVID-19 and it may be present with more common features such as 
breathlessness, fever, and cough. CT-finding of localized ground-glass opacity is also supportive of 
the diagnosis. Other atypical manifestations of COVID-19 include: • Respiratory- • Pulmonary embolism • Hemoptysis • Cardiac- • Myocardial infarction • Myocarditis • Pericarditis • Pericardial effusion • Neurological- • Stroke • Guillain■Barre Syndrome • Viral encephalitis • Toxic encephalopathy • Acute hemorrhagic necrotizing encephalopathy • Olfactory and taste disorders • Gastrointestinal- • Diarrhea • Nausea • Vomiting • Abdominal pain • Ocular- • Conjunctivitis • Epiphora • Cutaneous- • Erythematous rash • Widespread urticaria • Chickenpox■like vesicles • Localized pruritic lesions • Petechial skin rash 1518 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Tuberculosis would have a more chronic history and radiologically appears as dense, 
homogeneous parenchymal consolidation in subpleural sites of lower and middle lobes. Option B: In necrotising pneumonia, CT imaging is likely to show distinct areas of low attenuation 
with decreased parenchymal enhancement representing liquefaction. Option D: Invasive aspergillosis is likely to occur in the setting of immunosuppression. The 
associated ground glass opacity, occurring due to hemorrhage, surrounds a pulmonary nodule and 
is known as the halo sign.

questions.question: Question 12: What is the most common lung pathology seen during the autopsy of COVID-19 patients?
questions.explanation:
Diffuse alveolar damage is the most common lung pathology noted during the autopsy of 
COVID-19 patients. COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include: • Diffuse alveolar damage • Hyaline membrane formation • Desquamation of pneumocytes • Fibrin deposits in lungs • Inflammation with mononuclear cells Note: Diffuse alveolar damage is not specific to COVID-19. It may be seen in all cases of acute 
respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) including pneumonia, burns, near drowning, etc
